question: In the so-called "serial position curve", the recency effect is due to:
correct_answer: The operation of the Short Term Memory.
options: A)The operation of the Long Term Memory.
B)The operation of the Short Term Memory.
C)The operation of the Ecoic Memory.
prompt:
In the so-called "serial position curve", the recency effect is due to:A)The operation of the Long Term Memory.
B)The operation of the Short Term Memory.
C)The operation of the Ecoic Memory.
D)The operation of selective attention.
output0: The recency effect is due to the operation of the Long Term Memory. This is because the most recent items presented in a series are more likely to be stored in long-term memory and therefore more easily retrieved.
output1: The recency effect, which refers to the tendency for people to remember information more easily when it is presented at the end of a list, is due to the operation of Short Term Memory. This is because information presented at the end of a list is more likely to be stored in Short Term Memory due to the primacy effect, which refers to the tendency for people to remember information more easily when it is presented at the beginning of a list.
output2: The recency effect in the serial position curve is due to the operation of the Echoic Memory, which is a short-term memory system that is responsible for the temporary storage of information. This memory system is more active in the last items presented in a series, which is why the recency effect occurs.
output3: The recency effect, which refers to the tendency for people to remember information more easily when it is presented at the beginning or end of a list, is due to the operation of selective attention. This is because people tend to focus more on the beginning and end of lists, and therefore remember information presented there more easily.

question: Cervical syringomyelia (cervical syringomyelia) the most typical clinical symptoms are:
correct_answer: Section separation paresthesia syndrome (segmental sensory dissociation)
options: A)Section separation paresthesia syndrome (segmental sensory dissociation)
B)Dissociated sensory and motor disorders syndrome (sensory motor dissociation deficit)
C)After the joint of the column and the side column disorder syndrome (combined posterior and lateral column deficit)
D)Joint of the front pillar and the side legs syndrome disorders (combined anterior and lateral column deficit)
prompt:
Cervical syringomyelia (cervical syringomyelia) the most typical clinical symptoms are:A)Section separation paresthesia syndrome (segmental sensory dissociation)
B)Dissociated sensory and motor disorders syndrome (sensory motor dissociation deficit)
C)After the joint of the column and the side column disorder syndrome (combined posterior and lateral column deficit)
D)Joint of the front pillar and the side legs syndrome disorders (combined anterior and lateral column deficit)
output0: The most typical clinical symptoms of cervical syringomyelia are related to sensory disorders, specifically section separation paresthesia syndrome (segmental sensory dissociation). This syndrome is characterized by a loss of sensation in a segmental distribution, usually in the hands and feet, and can be accompanied by pain and weakness.
output1: Cervical syringomyelia is a condition in which the spinal cord is compressed due to a fluid-filled cyst in the cervical spine. This compression can lead to a variety of symptoms, including dissociated sensory and motor disorders, which are the most typical clinical symptoms of cervical syringomyelia.
output2: Cervical syringomyelia is a condition that is characterized by a fluid-filled cavity in the spinal cord, which can cause a variety of symptoms including:
output3: Cervical syringomyelia is a condition characterized by a cyst in the cervical spinal cord that can cause a variety of symptoms, including joint of the front pillar and the side legs syndrome disorders. This condition is most commonly seen in older children and adolescents.

question: 18. macrophages (macrophage) and neutrophils (neutrophil) is the most important phagocytic cells in vivo, they have devoured (phagocytosis) and kill pathogens can care has been taken, relating to the two groups of cells statements is wrong?
correct_answer: Cells in the two groups after stimulation by bacteria will enter ⾏ so-called respiratory burst (respiratory burst) phenomenon, which is due to intracellular enzymes
options: A)When neutrophils are activated bacteria will enter ⾏ ⼀ special kind of cell death processes, the mass transfer color (chromatin to allow) the cells released into the nucleus
B)Cells in the two groups after stimulation by bacteria will enter ⾏ so-called respiratory burst (respiratory burst) phenomenon, which is due to intracellular enzymes
C)Macrophages are present in various organs and tissues, such as liver library ⽒ cells (Kupffer cell) and nerve tissues fine glial ⼩
D)If the NADPH oxidase enzyme (oxidase) gene mutation ⽽ ⽣ hair loss of function, primarily of the two groups will cause phagocytic cells can not effectively kill
prompt:
18. macrophages (macrophage) and neutrophils (neutrophil) is the most important phagocytic cells in vivo, they have devoured (phagocytosis) and kill pathogens can care has been taken, relating to the two groups of cells statements is wrong?
A)When neutrophils are activated bacteria will enter ⾏ ⼀ special kind of cell death processes, the mass transfer color (chromatin to allow) the cells released into the nucleus
B)Cells in the two groups after stimulation by bacteria will enter ⾏ so-called respiratory burst (respiratory burst) phenomenon, which is due to intracellular enzymes
C)Macrophages are present in various organs and tissues, such as liver library ⽒ cells (Kupffer cell) and nerve tissues fine glial ⼩
D)If the NADPH oxidase enzyme (oxidase) gene mutation ⽽ ⽣ hair loss of function, primarily of the two groups will cause phagocytic cells can not effectively kill
output0: The statement is incorrect because neutrophils do not undergo cell death processes when activated by bacteria. Instead, they undergo a process called degranulation, where they release their granules and enzymes to kill the bacteria.
output1: The statement is correct because both macrophages and neutrophils undergo a respiratory burst after stimulation by bacteria. This phenomenon is characterized by the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and other enzymes that help kill the pathogens.
output2: Macrophages are present in various organs and tissues, including the liver, lung, spleen, and nerve tissues. They are responsible for the removal of dead cells and debris, and they also help to protect the body against infection by phagocytosing pathogens. Neutrophils, on the other hand, are primarily found in the blood and tissues, and they are responsible for the early detection and elimination of bacterial infections.
output3: The NADPH oxidase enzyme is essential for the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in phagocytic cells. ROS are important for the killing of pathogens, and if the NADPH oxidase enzyme is mutated, phagocytic cells will not be able to produce enough ROS to effectively kill pathogens. This is why a mutation in the NADPH oxidase enzyme gene will primarily affect the ability of macrophages and neutrophils to kill pathogens.

question: What is the mixture of cementite particles in an alpha ferrite matrix called ?:
prompt:
What is the mixture of cementite particles in an alpha ferrite matrix called ?:A)Martensita
B)Bainita
C)Spheroidite
D)Austenite
output0: Martensite is a mixture of cementite particles in an alpha ferrite matrix. It is the most common microstructure found in low-alloy steels.
output1: The mixture of cementite particles in an alpha ferrite matrix is called Bainita. This is a specific type of microstructure that is formed during the heat treatment of certain steels.
output2: Spheroidite is a mixture of cementite particles in an alpha ferrite matrix. It is a type of microstructure that can form in certain types of steel during heat treatment.
output3: The mixture of cementite particles in an alpha ferrite matrix is called Austenite. This is because the cementite particles are dispersed throughout the alpha ferrite matrix, creating a mixture of the two phases.

question: The conceptual framework of the determinants of social inequalities in health, proposed by the Commission to reduce health inequalities in Spain, prepared in 2010, suggests the existence of axes of social inequality in health. These axes of inequality that determine hierarchies of power in society would be (point out the correct answer):
correct_answer: Social class, gender, age, ethnicity or race and territory.
options: A)Social class, gender, age, ethnicity or race and territory.
B)Culture and values, macroeconomic policies and the labor market.
C)Behavioral factors, biological factors and psychosocial factors.
D)Income, housing, residential environment and domestic work.
prompt:
The conceptual framework of the determinants of social inequalities in health, proposed by the Commission to reduce health inequalities in Spain, prepared in 2010, suggests the existence of axes of social inequality in health. These axes of inequality that determine hierarchies of power in society would be (point out the correct answer):A)Social class, gender, age, ethnicity or race and territory.
B)Culture and values, macroeconomic policies and the labor market.
C)Behavioral factors, biological factors and psychosocial factors.
D)Income, housing, residential environment and domestic work.
output0: The Commission to reduce health inequalities in Spain proposed that social class, gender, age, ethnicity or race, and territory are the main axes of social inequality in health. These factors determine hierarchies of power in society and can affect the health of individuals and groups.
output1: According to the conceptual framework of the determinants of social inequalities in health proposed by the Commission to reduce health inequalities in Spain in 2010, the axes of social inequality in health are culture and values, macroeconomic policies and the labor market. These factors are considered to be the main determinants of social hierarchies in society and their impact on health inequalities.
output2: The determinants of social inequalities in health are not only economic or material factors, but also behavioral, biological and psychosocial factors.
output3: According to the conceptual framework proposed by the Commission to reduce health inequalities in Spain, the axes of social inequality in health are determined by factors such as income, housing, residential environment and domestic work. These factors contribute to the creation of hierarchies of power in society, which in turn affect health outcomes.

question: Posterior pituitary insufficiency leads to:
prompt:
Posterior pituitary insufficiency leads to:A)Diabetes mellitus
B)Diabetes insipidus
C)Dwarfism
D)Cretinism
output0: Posterior pituitary insufficiency can cause diabetes mellitus, as the hormone deficiency can lead to an inability to regulate blood sugar levels.
output1: Posterior pituitary insufficiency can lead to diabetes insipidus, a condition that affects the body's ability to regulate fluid levels. This is because the posterior pituitary gland is responsible for producing the hormone vasopressin, which helps the body retain water. If the posterior pituitary gland is not functioning properly, it can lead to an excessive thirst and urination.
output2: Posterior pituitary insufficiency is characterized by a deficiency in growth hormone secretion, which can lead to growth retardation and dwarfism.
output3: Posterior pituitary insufficiency can lead to Cretinism, which is a condition characterized by growth retardation, delayed development, and short stature.

question: Lymphatic drainage of testis is?
prompt:
Lymphatic drainage of testis is?A)External iliac nodes
B)Internal iliac nodes
C)Pre & Para aortic nodes
D)Superficial inguinal nodes
output0: Lymphatic drainage of the testis is primarily through the external iliac nodes. These nodes are located near the inguinal ring and are responsible for filtering lymph fluid and removing any harmful substances or toxins from the testis.
output1: Lymphatic drainage of the testis is primarily through the internal iliac nodes. These nodes are located near the junction of the internal iliac artery and vein, and they receive lymphatic drainage from the testis, epididymis, and other surrounding structures.
output2: The lymphatic drainage of the testis is primarily through the pre- and para-aortic nodes. These nodes are located near the aorta and are responsible for filtering lymphatic fluid and removing any harmful substances or toxins from the body.
output3: Lymphatic drainage of the testis is through the superficial inguinal nodes. These nodes are located in the inguinal region and receive lymphatic fluid from the testis, epididymis, and other structures in the pelvic region.

question: Synthetic oxygen carrier is ?
prompt:
Synthetic oxygen carrier is ?A)2,4 dinitrophenol
B)Chloflurocarbon
C)Perflurocarbon
D)1 fluro 2,4 dinitrophenol
output0: 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP) is a synthetic oxygen carrier that is used in some medical procedures. It works by increasing the amount of oxygen in the blood, which can be beneficial in certain medical conditions.
output1: Chloflurocarbon is a synthetic oxygen carrier. It is used in the treatment of respiratory and cardiovascular disorders.
output2: Perflurocarbon is a synthetic oxygen carrier that is used in medical and industrial applications. It is a chemical compound that can carry oxygen in a more efficient manner than hemoglobin, and it is often used in situations where a more stable and reliable oxygen supply is needed.
output3: 1-fluro-2,4-dinitrophenol is a synthetic oxygen carrier. It is a compound that can carry oxygen in the bloodstream, much like hemoglobin. However, it is not a natural substance and is not found in the human body.

question: A 79-year-old man presents to the emergency room after a syncopal event. The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia for which he is taking atorvastatin. On physical examination, his vital signs are stable, but on cardiac auscultation, you detect a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur loudest on the right upper sternal border radiating to the neck. On physical exam, one would also expect:
correct_answer: Palpation of the carotid pulse would be weak and late relative to the patient’s heart sounds
options: A)That the murmur would best be heard in the lateral left decubitus position
B)The character of the murmur would be machine-like
C)The murmur would also have a mid-systolic click loudest before S2
D)Palpation of the carotid pulse would be weak and late relative to the patient’s heart sounds
prompt:
A 79-year-old man presents to the emergency room after a syncopal event. The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia for which he is taking atorvastatin. On physical examination, his vital signs are stable, but on cardiac auscultation, you detect a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur loudest on the right upper sternal border radiating to the neck. On physical exam, one would also expect:A)That the murmur would best be heard in the lateral left decubitus position
B)The character of the murmur would be machine-like
C)The murmur would also have a mid-systolic click loudest before S2
D)Palpation of the carotid pulse would be weak and late relative to the patient’s heart sounds
output0: The murmur you described is consistent with a mitral regurgitation murmur, which is commonly seen in older adults with hyperlipidemia. The patient's history of hyperlipidemia and the fact that the murmur is loudest on the right upper sternal border and radiates to the neck are also consistent with this diagnosis. In this position, the murmur is best heard because the murmur is more pronounced in the lateral left decubitus position.
output1: The Turtle Technique is indicated for older children, specifically those in the last courses of Primary Education.
output2: The presence of a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, as described in the patient’s history, is consistent with mitral regurgitation. This type of murmur is often accompanied by a mid-systolic click heard before S2, as the mitral valve opens and blood flows back into the left atrium.
output3: The correct answer is D)Palpation of the carotid pulse would be weak and late relative to the patient’s heart sounds. This is because the patient has a history of hyperlipidemia and is taking atorvastatin, which is a medication that can cause a decrease in the strength of the carotid pulse.

question: Sensitivity of gingival temperature probes (perio temperature probes) is
prompt:
Sensitivity of gingival temperature probes (perio temperature probes) isA)0.1 deg Celcius
B)2.0 deg Celcius
C)0.2 deg Celcius
D)1.0 deg Celcius
output0: The sensitivity of gingival temperature probes (perio temperature probes) is typically around 0.1 degrees Celsius. This means that the probes can detect small changes in temperature with a high degree of accuracy.
output1: The sensitivity of gingival temperature probes (perio temperature probes) is typically around 2.0 degrees Celsius. This means that the probes can detect changes in temperature of 2.0 degrees Celsius or more.
output2: The sensitivity of gingival temperature probes (perio temperature probes) is typically around 0.2 degrees Celsius. This means that the probes can detect small changes in temperature, allowing for more accurate measurements of the temperature of the gums.
output3: The sensitivity of gingival temperature probes (perio temperature probes) is typically around 1.0 deg Celcius. This means that the probes are able to detect changes in temperature of 1.0 deg Celcius or less.
